Award.AwardTitle: Workshop/Collaborative Research: NSF Proposal Writing Workshop at 46th SME NAMRC and ASME MSEC 2018; Texas A&M University; College Station, Texas; June 18, 2018

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funds to conduct a National Science Foundation (NSF) proposal-writing workshop concurrent with the 46th Society of Manufacturing Engineers North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2018). The workshop will be held at Texas A&M University on Monday, June 18, 2018, building on the success of previous similar workshops held at the three previous NAMRC/MSEC conferences. The aim of the workshop is to aid future NSF proposal submitters in communicating clear research objectives and improving proposal quality. Participants will learn guidelines for writing a quality NSF proposal with an emphasis on the research objective. Interactions during the workshop will help build meaningful collaborations. This will positively affect the attendees' academic career and, subsequently, will help develop the nation's human resources. Additionally, when proposals are well written, the reviews tend to be more consistent and NSF panel meetings are more efficient.

Major activities of the workshop include: presentations by NSF program directors, breakout sessions to discuss example research objectives, a group question/answer period, and a conclusions session. Professors and graduate students from across the US will be invited to attend the workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An NSF proposal writing workshop was held on June 18, 2018, at Texas A&M University. The workshop was collocated with the 46th SME North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the 2018 ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2018).  The workshop aimed to aid future NSF proposal submitters in communicating clear research objectives and improving proposal quality. Major activities of the workshop included: (1) presentations by workshop organizers, (2) group writing exercise during lunch, (3) individual activities to practice defining a research objective, (4) group activity to discuss example research summaries, and (5) question/answer period with NSF personnel. This workshop built on the success of the 2015, 2016, and 2017 NSF proposal writing workshops held in Charlotte, NC, Blacksburg, VA, and Los Angeles, CA, respectively.

About 55 professors and graduate students attended the workshop. They learned guidelines for writing a quality research objective.  Interactions during the workshop with colleagues helped foster meaningful collaborations.  The relationships developed during the workshop will positively affect the attendees' academic careers and, subsequently, will help develop the nation's human resources.  Additionally, by improving the participants? proposals, the panel reviews will be more consistent.  This will help in making the NSF panel review meetings run more smoothly.
